article_title: Patients should be able to focus on fighting cancer, not insurer
article_text:
Patients should be able to focus on fighting cancer, not insurer

Photo: Karen Warren, Staff Barbara Holt comforts husband Duane Rossmann while he receives... The irony is not lost on Duane Rossmann, a health care consultant for 40 years.

article_metadata.description: For the past six days, he lay in a hospital bed at M.D. Anderson, an IV in his arm delivering chemotherapy to fight the Stage 4 lymphoma ravaging his body, while his wife frantically worked the phones to figure out how to pay for the fourth round of treatment after their insurance company discontinued his policy.  [...] October, the father of three and grandfather of two (plus one on the way) had been mostly healthy his entire life and paid for benefits he didn't really need.  [...] they never were.  Members have been invited to purchase HMO plans, which do not include as in-network providers some of Houston's top-tier institutions, including M.D. Anderson, Memorial Hermann, Methodist and Texas Children's Hospitals.  Asked how much the company made overall, how much it added to its reserves, how much, if anything, it returned to policyholders in recent years, and how many, if any, exemptions it granted to patients in active treatment, the president said simply, "I don't know."  When I asked later how that meshed with canceling the policies of people in active cancer treatment, he modified his wording to say the company does "everything in our power" to stand by members.  [...] it's a mess.  What could Texas leaders have done to sign up more healthy people to balance the risk pool, so insurers wouldn't lose so much money?
article_metadata.author.name: By Lisa Falkenberg
